loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Yaneth Del Socorro

texts.es: Yaneth con su anterior credikiva compró insumos para prepara las comidas en su restaurante y ganó descuentos por su compra de contado y en mayor volumen. También su credikiva le alcanzó para comprar sillas, mesas, y artículos que habían pedido sus clientes como ropa infantil pues está iniciando una nueva actividad, con la cual planea aprovechar el mercado de su restaurante que es fijo y proveerles las mercancías variadas que su familia requiere. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a un nuevo credikiva con el que invertirá en ropa y surtirá su tenderete, para dar satisfacción al mercado y para ella poder generar un poco mas de ingresos. Ella envía un mensaje de agradecimiento  a los financiadores de Kiva y es el siguiente: “Les agradezco mucho, ojalá me sigan apoyando a mi y a otros microempresarios.“
texts.en: With her last Kiva loan Yaneth bought supplies to make food for her restaurant, and obtained discounts by paying cash and buying in bulk.  Her loan was also enough for her to buy chairs, tables and items that her customers had asked her for such as children's clothing.  She is starting a new business, with which she plans to take advantage of the customer base of her restaurant, which is steady, and provide them with items that they require for their families. For this reason she is requesting a new Kiva loan, which she will invest in clothing and supply her clothing stall, in order to satisfy her customers and earn more income.  She sends the following message of gratitude to Kiva lenders: "I thank you very much, and hope you will continue supporting me and other microbusiness owners".

loans.use: to buy clothing and supply her clothing stall, in order to satisfy her customers.

loans.name: Sedjro Group

texts.fr: SEDJRO est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres exercent leurs activités dans la même zone. Le représentant du groupe, Adandé Jules (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgé de 28 ans et est un célibataire. Adandé Jules a arrêté l’école au niveau secondaire. Adandé Jules vit seul et assure seul ses divers besoins. Pour ce faire, il y a près de trois ans que Adandé Jules mène comme activité la vente des céréales (maïs, sorgho) dans sa région. Adandé Jules s’approvisionne dans une région du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Adandé Jules sollicite un premier crédit ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe SEDJRO. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en: The Sedjro group is composed of three members working in the same zone. The group’s representative, Adandé Jules (the one raising his hand in the photo) is 28 years old and single. Adandé Jules has left school at the secondary level. Adandé Jules lives alone and supports himself. In order to do so, he has been selling cereals (corn, sorghum) in his region for three years. He stocks up in a region of Benin. With the goal of meeting customer demand, Adandé Jules, together with the other members of the Sedjro group, is seeking his first loan. This loan will allow the group members to better meet demand and to increase their revenues.

loans.use: to buy cereals (corn, sorghum).

loans.name: Radha Krushna Group

texts.en:
This group formed in the year 2009 and is called “Radha Krushna” (named after the Hindu Lord Krishna and His power). It is a group comprised of four women members of the village called Dumerbahal. It is located in the Nuapada district; one of the poorest districts of India. One of the members of this group is Dibyarani who has raised her hand in the photo. She is 26 years old and her family consists of her husband, one small daughter, father in-law and mother in-law. Dibyarani has been running a small bakery factory in her house with the help of her husband for the last 12 years. In the factory, bakery items like bread, cream roll and toast etc. are being prepared. She has engaged four skilled laborers for the processing and making of the bakery items. Her husband supplies the products to three or four nearby towns within a 40 km radius. Dibyarani says owing to better quality, design, packing and forms of her products, there is a lot of demand from the locals, but due to a shortage of stock she could not meet their demands. She does not like to say “No” to her customers and wants to give better service to her customers. She now wants to buy more stock of oil, dough, etc. to increase her production level to meet the demands and grab her customers. A portion of the loan will be used to purchase raw materials in bulk, which will reduce her purchasing and transportation costs. As the present location of the factory is in her residence, Dibyarani wants to construct a separate house in a prominent place in her locality to run the business smoothly. She also hopes to save money from the sale proceeds for provide a better education facility to her only girl child.

The other three active members of the group are Nabina, who has a sweets-making business and grocery shop, Jajnaseni, who sells and supplies bakery items, and Rangalata who has a grocery business and hopes to provide better education to their children and increase their living standard.

loans.use: to purchase oil, dough, sugar etc.

loans.name: Orokia's Group

texts.fr:
Mme OROKIA représente le groupe DIOUGOU SOMPRIN. Elle se porte bien ainsi que tout le groupe. Mariée, elle est mère de 02 enfants. Le plus âgé a 15ans et le moins âgé a 12ans. Tous vont à l’école et elle a 04 personnes en charge.

Mme vend habits et oignons depuis 10ans. Son prêt s’est bien déroulé. Elle s’approvisionne à Gounra (Lanfiara) frontière Tiébélé. Ses clients sont hommes et femmes.

Mme veut s’acheter 15sacs d’oignons et 20complet pagnes.

Avec ses économies, elle veut aider  à la scolarisation des enfants et épargner. Elle tient toujours son ambition  d’ouvrir un magasin.
texts.en:
Orokia is the representative of the DIOUGOU SOMPRIN group.  She is doing well, and so are the other members of the group.  She is married and the mother of two children, ages 15 and 12, who both go to school.  Orokia has four people in her care.

Orokia has been selling clothes and onions for ten years.  There has been no problem with her loan.  

Orokia buys her goods in Gounra (Lanfiara), near Tiébélé, and she sells to both men and women.

She wants to buy 15 bags of onions and 20 "pagnes" (colorful West-African fabrics), measuring 1 x 3 meters each.

She wants to use her savings to contribute to her children's education.  She also wants to continue to save some money.  Her ambition is still to open a shop.

loans.use: to buy 15 bags of onions and 20 "pagnes" (measuring 1 x 3 meters each).

loans.name: Maa Laxmi Group

texts.en:
This group is called Maa Laxmi (named after the Hindu Goddess of wealth). Its five members are all women who belong to the Below Poverty Line category (BPL) from the village called Gadramunda. It is located in the block of Khariar of Nuapada district of Odisha, one of the poorest districts in India, specially known for drought. Among the five members is Panchu. The lady sitting in the middle raising her hand is Panchu. She is 29 years old; living with her husband, three sons aged 10, 8 & 5 years and one daughter who is 2 years old. She is a very active lady and fond of cooking. She has been running a snacks & sweets-making and supply business at her house with the help of her husband for a couple of years. She initially started with two varieties and slowly expanded to three different varieties. She, along with her husband, cook local salty snacks named 'Namkin' (locally popular food of triangular shape and salty in taste), “Gaja” (fried dough dipped in sugar syrup) & Ladduu (one type of round shaped sweet) and make packages. Her husband travels to the surrounding villages selling to local shops there. He travels almost 40 km in a day. She and her husband spend almost four hours a day making snacks and packets and selling them.  In this process, her family earns a profit of rupees 200/- to 250/- daily. For raw materials like cooking oil, sugar and dough, her husband travels to the nearby town frequently every three days and spend more time and transportation cost. She now wants to have a stock of raw materials like cooking oil, sugar and dough, so that they have enough stock to carry on their business regularly with out any intervention. Panchu has planned to use a portion of the loan to buy the raw materials in bulk, saving the transportation cost and getting a cash discount. She hopes to complete her half-built house and start a screen printing business as her husband has sufficient experience in that field by using the rest of her loan. 

The other four members of the group are Sasirekha, Jachana, Pana and Suraj and they have businesses like selling milk, running a grocery shop and cultivating vegetables.

loans.use: to purchase dough, sugar, oil etc

loans.name: Maa Maheswari Group

texts.en:
The name of this group is Maa Maheswari (named after a village deity of the locality). All four women members of this group belong to Kurebhana village in Bolangir district in Odisha, India and are in the BPL (Below Poverty Line) category.  People from the BPL category live on less than one dollar a day. Saila, sitting in the middle with her hand raised in the photo, is one of the members of this group. She is 40 years old and lives with her husband, two daughters who are 17 and 15 years old and a son who is 19 years old.
 
Saila’s husband is landless. He does daily labor and earn a very small income. Saila runs a milk processing unit at her house. She has only one cow, which produces 8 to 10 liters of milk per day. As the milk is not sufficient, Saila and her husband go to three or four nearby villages and collect 200 liters of milk per day to process and produce milk products like Paneer, Chhena (cheese), butter, ghee, khua and Peda (a sweet item made of khua) and sell them to earn an income of Rs 400 to Rs 500 per day in the off season (August-October). In the peak season, i.e. in the marriage season, (November-July) they earn Rs 1,000 to Rs 1,500 per day by selling the milk products. She employs a person to help her in the processing. She has a small freezer to keep the products and supply in the market but it is insufficient for her. With the loan, she is planning to purchase a deep freezer of 1500 kgs capacity to store the milk products for days together and sell them at peak time to earn more profit. In addition, she has a plan to construct a cement kiln for her processing unit. At present, she is educating her children in the nearby high school and college. As providing college education is very expensive,  she is trying to increase her income to meet the demands of her children. She has another plan to construct a house, as the present house is crowded..   

The other three members of her group (Jayanti, Sanjukta & Kahara) are running grocery shops and a milk business, respectively.

loans.use: to purchase a deep freezer and build a kiln.

loans.name: Vangie

texts.en:
This is Vangie, 40, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Christopher, an electrician, and is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Vangie operates a food stall. She sells some snack foods like banana cue and glazed sweet potatoes. Basically, these are just banana and sweet potato that are being cooked with sugar in boiling oil. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20, 000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more quantities of products like banana, sweet potato, sugar and oil. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Vangie dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have a good life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:

She, together with her husband, manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Catherine operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5-pesos-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippines pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Ricarda

texts.es:
La socia es la señora Ricarda, ahora tiene 44 años de edad, está casada y tiene 4 hijos,  vive en el distrito de Tambo Real, la socia se sigue dedicando a la   elaboración de productos lácteos como queso y yogurt, además de esto, ella también se dedica a la crianza de animales menores como cuyes y gallinas y a la agricultura produciendo productos como papa y maíz.
Ricarda necesita elaborar más queso y yogurt, por ello invertirá su préstamo solicitado en  comprar leche para la fabricación del queso y del yogurt.
La socia está muy agradecida con KIVA por ayudarla a desarrollarse en su actividad y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas. Ricarda pertenece al banco comunal “San Bartolo de Tambo Real” distrito de Tambo Real de la provincia de Anta en Cusco – Perú.
Ricarda quiere proporcionarles una mejor vida y educación a sus hijos,  y por ellos se sacrifica, así que espera trabajar mucho y ahorrar para invertir en la educación de ellos.
texts.en:
Ricarda, now 44, is married and has four children. She lives in the Tambo Real district. She still works producing dairy products like cheese and yogurt. She also works raising small animals like guinea pigs and chickens and growing crops like potatoes and corn. She needs to make more cheese and yogurt, so she will invest her loan in milk to make them. 

Ricarda is very thankful to Kiva for helping her develop her business and she promises to make her payments on time. She belongs to the communal bank "San Bartolo de Tambo Real", in the Tambo Real District, Anta Province, in Cusco, Peru. She wants to provide a better life and better education for her children, and she sacrifices for them. This is why she hopes to work a lot and save to invest in their education.

loans.use: to buy cow's milk for the production of cheese and yogurt.

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
This is Aurora, 60, resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Cesar, her business partner, and is the mother to their children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Aurora operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings when all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands cost less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings, and frozen food products. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Aurora dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her own restaurant. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes, a resident of Tondo, Philippines, is married to Domingo. She, together with her children, manage their own household while operating a retail meat business. She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Mercedes retails processed meat products. She buys processed meat products from a wholesaler then sells the meat per piece/pack for a profit. Products can range from ham, hot dogs, processed pork and similar products. Customers are attracted by the low selling prices and choices she offers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue her business, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. With the loan, she will buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Mercedes hopes to be able to expand soon, as she dreams to be able to give her children a high-quality education through her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of frozen food needed in her business.

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita, 50, is a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Mario and a mother to her children. She manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Clarita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. She also has a feather duster business. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 16,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Clarita hopes to grow her business and dreams to give her family a good future through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa, 38, is a resident of Tondo, Philippines. She is married to Bernardo, a vendor, and is a mother to her children. She manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Theresa operates a buy and sell business. She buys general merchandise from wholesalers and sells it for a little profit. Her products include different slippers for men, women and children. Customers are attracted by the low selling prices and the many choices she offers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.
To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy ready-to-wear products and merchandise items to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Theresa hopes to be able to expand her business in the coming years and draw her family more closely to God. She dreams to giver her family a good life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stocks of general merchandise needed in her business.

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en:
Esmeralda previously accessed a 28,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her family's personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in higher profits. Her profits from business will definitely help to sustain her family’s daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Esmeralda hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams of giving her family a good future through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy grocery items and products needed for her business.

loans.name: Gil

texts.en:
Gil previously accessed an 18,000 PHP loan that he used to purchase school supplies to expand his product inventory. His earnings were a big help for the education of his children and in his family's personal, household and business expenditures. 

He would like to apply for a 50,000 PHP loan to buy more school supplies. The more items displayed at the store the better, resulting in higher profits. His profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain his family's daily needs and educational expenses of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Gil hopes to be able to expand soon. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for school supplies needed in his business.

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion, 37, is a resident of Bacoor, Cavite Philippines. She is married to Roger, a motorized tricycle driver, and is a mother to her children. She and her husband manage their own household. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Salvacion oversees operations of their motorized tricycle transportation business. They have one tricycle that carries up to four passengers to their destination within the community. The tricycle driver then remits a boundary (daily quota) each day to her. In her business the regular customers are the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy spare parts, accessories and to pay for the maintenance of their motorized tricycle. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Salvacion dreams to be able to give her children a high quality education through all her hard work. She hopes to buy a second tricycle. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and maintenance of her motorized tricycle.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina, 53, is a resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. She manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for everyday expenses.

Angelina operates a market stall. She sells fruits and vegetable products in the community market. She buys quantities of fruits and vegetables and sells the produce per kilo. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of fruits and vegetables to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Angelina dreams to give her children a high-quality education. She hopes to have a good life someday through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for vegetables and fruits needed in her business.

loans.name: Sitti Rachidam

texts.en:
Sitti Rashidam, 34, is a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Steve and is a mother to her children. She and her husband manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Sitti Rashidam operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Sitti Rashhidam hopes to grow her business and dreams to give her family a good future through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
This is Mirasol, 48, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Nixon, an engineer, and is the mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Mirasol operates a mineral water station. She retails mineral water to her customers, selling to them per container (5 gallons per container) for a profit. Her regular customers for her mineral water are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy an additional machine for alkaline processing. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Mirasol dreams of expanding and having new branches in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for an additional machine for alkaline processing needed in her business.

loans.name: Juan Jose

texts.es: Juan Jose de 22 años de edad vive en Bolivia, es soltero y no tiene hijos, actualmente sigue estudiando en la Universidad y a la ves trabaja en la empresa comercial EDSON de mensajero, también se dedica a la agricultura donde siembran papa en las tierras de su madre, es un joven humilde y trabajador, él trabaja para poder pagar sus estudios y ayudar a su familia, su padre tuvo un accidente hace muchos años donde esta incapacitado para trabajar así que él tiene que ayudar a su madre con los gastos familiares y a la ves poder pagar sus estudios de la Universidad Juan Jose estudia por las madrugadas y por las noches y en el día restante trabaja. El presente crédito que solicita es para la compra de semilla de papa y abonos químicos, Juan Jose no cuenta con mucho capital para su inversión de su cultivo así es que él requiere el préstamo para poder cultivar papa y poder ayudar a su madre y mejorar sus ingresos para poder colaborar con los gastos familiares.
texts.en:
Juan Jose, 22, lives in Bolivia. He is a single and does not have children. Currently, he continues his studies at the University and at the same time he works at a company called EDSON as a messenger. He also makes his living in farming where he sows potatoes on his mother’s land.  He is a humble and hardworking young man.  He works to pay for his studies and help his family.  His father had an accident many years ago and is unable to work so he must help his mother with household expenses and at the same time pay for his schooling at the University. Juan Jose studies in the early morning and in the evening.  During the day, he works. 

The loan he is requesting is for the purchase of potato seeds and fertilizer. Juan Jose does not have much capital to invest in his crop so he is requesting this loan to grow potatoes so that he can help his mother and increase his earnings to that he can help with household expenses.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and potato seeds.

loans.name: Wangninangbe Group

texts.fr: WANGNINANGBE est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres résident dans la même région au Bénin. La représentante du groupe, Louise (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 35 ans et est mariée à un certain Eugène. Le couple a cinq enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Louise vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges du ménage. Louise n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a près de quatorze ans que Louise mène comme activité la vente de divers produits et des chaussures. Louise exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Louise s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Louise sollicite un premier crédit avec les autres membres du groupe WANGNINANGBE. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en:
Wangninangbe is a group of three people who all live in the same area of Benin. 

The representative of the group, Louise (whose hand is raised in the photo), is 35 years old and is married to a man named Eugène. They have five children, all of whom have had schooling and are still under their parents' care. Louise lives together with her children and her husband. Together, the couple takes care of their household needs. Louise did not go to school. 

For almost 14 years, Louise has been running a business selling shoes and other various goods. She conducts her business passionately; this allows her to support herself and her children. Louise buys her goods from a market in Benin. 

In order to satisfy her customers, Louise is seeking this first loan with the other members of the Wangninangbe group. This loan will help Louise better respond to the needs of her customers and increase her profits.

loans.use: to buy shoes and other various goods

loans.name: Olga

texts.es: Olga de 59 años de edad es una mujer viuda y madre de 4 hijos en las edades de 22 a 30 años. Ella heredo de su esposo fallecido, el negocio de vender productos artesanales y materias primas para la elaboración de manualidades como hamacas, bolsos mochilas y también vende,  hilos comunes, hilo, piola y otros a clientes que lo consumen y a intermediarios que lo venden. Sus ventas las realiza de contado la mayor parte pues tiene también clientes qu ele venden a crédito. Así mismo viaja a la ciudad de Barranquilla para hacer sus compras de insumos pues en esta ciudad encuentra precios razonables que le facilitan el sostenimiento de ella en el mercado.  En la actualidad está aplicando a su tercer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará materiales para vender en su negocio como hilazas de algodón, hilo acrílico, también hará reparaciones locativas en sus instalaciones y pondrá piso de cerámica. Con esta nueva inversión estará cumpliendo su meta de crecimiento y de mejoramiento de su vivienda la que es su mayor desafío.
texts.en:
Olga, 59, is a widow and a mother of four children between 22 and 30 years old. She inherited her late husband’s business of selling handmade products and raw materials for making crafts such as hammocks and bags. The business also sells thread, wire, string, and other things to customers and middlemen that resell it. The majority of sales are made using cash and some customers receive goods on credit. In addition, she travels to the city of Barranquilla to buy her supplies because she finds reasonable prices there which help her maintain her place in the market. 

She is currently requesting her third loan with Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo which she will use to buy materials to sell in her business such as cotton thread and acrylic thread. She will also make improvements to her business and put in a ceramic floor.  With this new investment, she will fulfil her goal of growth and improvement of her property which is her biggest challenge.

loans.use: to buy material to sell in her home such as cotton thread and acrylic thread. It also helps her make repairs to her business and put in a ceramic floor.

loans.name: Salvador

texts.es:
Don Salvador tiene 44 años de edad, es casado y tiene tres hijos una de 16 años que estudia bachillerato, y otro de 8 y 12 años de edad que estudian básica en la escuela. El  trabaja como vigilante en la noche y en el día sale a vender queso, crema y pan francés desde hace tres años.

El queso y la crema los compra una vez por semana en una ciudad que esta a 90 kilómetros de su casa; el pan francés lo compra en una comunidad cercana.

El préstamo esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar una motocicleta, para trasladarse al trabajo hacer las ventas a entregar el producto. Así, él tendrá un medio de transporte más rápido, para entregar los productos a sus clientes y ampliar su negocio. Su deseo es ahorrar para mejorar su vivienda y brindarle mejores condiciones de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Salvador is 44 years old, married, and has three children. He has a 16-year old daughter in high school, and 8 and 12-year old sons in elementary school. He works as a security guard during the night, and for the last three years he has sold cheese, cream and baguette bread during the day. Weekly, he buys cheese and cream from a city 90 km away. He buys the baguette bread in a community nearby.


He has requested a loan through Fundación Campo to buy a motorcycle to ride to work and to sell and deliver his products. This will give him faster transportation to deliver products to his customers and to grow his business. His goal is to save to improve his home and provide better living conditions for his family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to ride to work, make sales, and deliver the merchandise.

loans.name: Rodrigo

texts.es: Rodrigo de 24 años de edad vive en Bolivia - Cochabamba, es soltero y no tiene hijos, estudio hasta el nivel bachillerato no pudo culminar sus estudios, no contaba con mucha economía en su familia así que no pudo ejercer una carrera como él quería, desde muy pequeño él se supo a trabajar así ayudar en su familia y poder pagar su estudios. Rodrigo trabaja de transportista publico prestando sus servicios a la población de Cochabamba, ya que el corre mucho peligro que hay muchos asaltos y delincuencia para los trasportista, Rodrigo es trabajador, humilde y responsable. El presente crédito Solicitado por Rodrigo es para la refacción y mantenimiento de su auto ya que no cuenta con muchos ingresos y no puede cubrir los gastos de su mantenimiento, sin embargo él trabaja en esa situación de su auto por que necesita ayudar con los ingresos familiares para que puedan cubrir sus gastos.
texts.en:
Rodrigo, 24, lives in Cochabamba Bolivia. He is single and does not have children. He studied through the baccalaureate level at school, but could not complete his studies as his family did not have much money and therefore he could not pursue the career he wanted.  From an early age, he learned to work to help his family and pay for his schooling. Rodrigo works in public transport providing services to the people of Cochabamba although there are many assaults and crime.

Rodrigo is hardworking, humble, and responsible. The loan requested by Rodrigo is for the repair and maintenance of his car as he does not have much income and cannot cover maintenance costs. Nevertheless, he works in this industry with his car because he needs to help with household income so that they can cover their expenses.

loans.use: to repair and maintain his taxi.

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
This is Juanita, age 67, who is a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. She is married and a mother to her child. She and her husband manage their household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Juanita maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, undergarments, cosmetics, soaps and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller Life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealers' prices are lower than those in catalogs, resulting in the profits that dealers receive as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operating her business, Juanita is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Juanita hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams of creating a good life for her family. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stock of supplies and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Nerissa

texts.en:
This is Nerissa, age 41, who is a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Sherwin, a market inspector, and she is a mother to her children. Nerissa and her husband manage their household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Nerissa maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, undergarments, cosmetics, soaps and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller Life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealers' prices are lower than those in the catalogs, resulting in the profits that dealers earn as their income. Nerissa also sells peanut butter. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operating her business, Nerissa is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Nerissa hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams of creating a good life for her family. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and merchandise needed in her business.

loans.name: Fanny Del Socorro

texts.es: Fanny invirtió su anterior credikiva en materiales con los cuales elaboró sandalias en diferentes tallas,  que vendió a muchos más clientes que los usuales. Ella logró invertir en suelas gruesa y delgada, pegantes, capelladas y plataformas. Su satisfacción es cada vez mayor con lo que esta ocurriendo en su negocio,  por eso hoy se ha acercado nuevamente a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, para aplicar a un nuevo credikiva con el cual comprará 36 pares de hormas, para mejorar la calidad del calzado en diseño y en acabados, así mismo mejorará los tiempos productivos y tendrá diversidad de materias primas e insumos para la venta. Su mensaje a los financiadores de Kiva es que está muy agradecida con la organización, y que gracias a Dios ha quedado bien y ha logrado mejorar sus ingresos, con los que ha arreglado su casa, y pide por eso que sigan apoyando a muchas mas personas.
texts.en:
Fanny invested her prior credikiva loan in materials that she used to make sandals in different sizes which she sold to many more clients than usual.  She invested in thin and thick soles, glues, toe covers, and platforms.  Her satisfaction is greater every time as she sees what is happening with her business.  

That is why today she has come back to Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo to apply for a new credikiva loan which she will use to buy 36 pairs of foot molds to improve the quality of the design and finishes of her footwear. In this way she will improve production time and will have a diverse array of raw materials and supplies for sale. Her message to Kiva lenders is that she is very grateful to the organization and, thanks to God, she has improved her income which she used to fix her home and asks that Kiva continue to support many more people.

loans.use: to buy 36 pairs of foot molds.

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
This is Marlyn, age 53, who is a resident of Payatas, Philippines. She is married to Johnny and is a mother to her children. She and her husband manage their household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Marlyn maintains a direct selling business. She sells shoes, clothing, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller Life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealers' prices are lower than those in the catalogs, resulting in the profits that dealers earn as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community members.  She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every week.

To help her continue operating her business, Marlyn is requesting a PHP 16,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Marlyn hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams of creating a good life for her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and merchandise needed in her business.

loans.name: Lida

texts.en:
This is Lida, age 49, who is a resident of Caloocan, Philippines. She is married to Jimmy, a warehouseman, and is a mother to her children. She and her husband manage their own household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Lida operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil or an egg. She earns money by buying supplies at wholesale prices and then selling them by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community members. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, Lida is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Lida hopes to grow her business and dreams of creating a good future for her family through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
This is Wilma, age 49, who is a resident of Caloocan, Philippines. She is married to Rene, a worker abroad, and is a mother of two children. She and her husband manage their own household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Wilma operates an internet café business. There is now a greater need than before for services like these as customers’ demand increases. Her main patrons are students, who require her services for school projects. She also has customers who need to rent computers for business purposes such as writing a resume and working on office projects as well as people who just love to surf the net and participate in social networks. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in profit every day.

To help her continue operating her business, Wilma is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional computer parts and accessories needed in her business. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Wilma dreams of giving her children a good and high-quality education. She hopes to be able to give her family a good life through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional computer parts and supplies needed in her business.

loans.name: Yuranis

texts.es: Yuranis de 22 años de edad  tiene un negocio donde provee a sus clientes comunicaciones por internet, recargas a celulares y también vende artículos de papelería y helados. Su negocio nació desde el mes de Julio del año 2006, pues aprendió el manejo de la tecnología de la informática,  como una gran diversión, por eso su padre la apoyó comprando 3 computadores para emprender la actividad generadora de ingresos  y desde ahí inició su camino al éxito, pues obtuvo buenos resultados, que le permitieron agregarle el servicio de impresión, comprando una máquina para ello, y el de llamadas internacionales, con los cuales fue conformando una clientela fija, que aprovechó adicionándole productos para la venta, que pudiera articular  con su actividad, como lo fueron los artículos de  papelería y la heladería. Sus principales clientes son los estudiantes, vecinos, empleados de empresas, que  acceden a los servicios de tecnología y compran la mañana hasta las 9 de la noche y   cada vez se esmera mas en atender a su cliente tanto como este lo necesite, porque quiere lograr el sueño de sentar las bases para que cuando sus hijos lleguen a su hogar, que conforma con su esposo, tengan todas la condiciones de bienestar para lograrlo. En la actualidad se ha acercado a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo,  para acceder a un credikiva con el que comprará equipos de cómputos nuevos para remplazar los que se encuentran obsoletos. Así proporcionará mayor velocidad en las tareas de informática que atraerán cada vez mas clientes potenciales y fidelizará a sus compradores fijos, ganando cada vez mas dinero en su trabajo.
texts.en:
Yuranis, 22, has a business where she provides to her customers Internet communications, cell phone recharging and also sells stationery supplies and ice cream. Her business was born in the month of July of 2006 since she learned how to handle computer technology as a big hobby. Her father supported her interest, purchasing three computers for her to initiate an income-generating business. So began her road to success as she made a good profit which allowed her to add printing services for which she purchased a machine, as well as international calling, by which she went about establishing a customer base, taking the opportunity to add products for sale that might fit well with her business, such as the stationery items and frozen treats. 

Her main customers are students, neighbors and business employees who access the technological services and make purchases from morning until 9 at night. She exerts herself constantly to tend to her customers' every need because she wants to achieve the dream of laying the foundations so that when her children arrive to the home she shares with her husband, they would have everything ready to achieve their well-being. Currently she has approached the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo in order to access a Kiva loan with which she will purchase new computer equipment to replace that which has become obsolete. In this way she will provide greater speed for computer tasks which will attract ever more potential customers and build the loyalty of her regular customers, earning more and more money for her work.

loans.use: to purchase new computer equipment.

loans.name: Sedjro Group

texts.fr: SEDJRO est un groupe de quatre personnes, dont les membres résident dans une même maison. La représentante du groupe, Élisabeth (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 37 ans et est mariée à un certain Lucien. Le couple a cinq enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Élisabeth et son mari vivent ensemble avec leurs enfants et assurent ensemble les différentes charges des enfants. Élisabeth n’a pas fréquenté l’école.  Il y a près de huit ans que Élisabeth mène comme activité la vente des galettes (faites à base de l’arachide et du maïs) à son domicile. Élisabeth exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Élisabeth s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle, Élisabeth sollicite un premier crédit avec les autres membres du groupe SEDJRO. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en:
Sedjro is a group of four people, who all live in the same house. The group’s representative is called Élisabeth (pictured with her hand raised in the photo), and she is 37 years of age. She is married to Lucien, and the couple has five children, all at school and all under their care. 

Élisabeth and her husband live together with their children, and together they ensure that their children are provided for. Élisabeth did not go to school, and for almost eight years has worked selling cookies (made from peanut and corn) from home. She is passionate about her business, and it allows her to provide for herself and for her children. 

Élisabeth gets her supplies from a market in Benin. In order to satisfy her customers, she has requested her first loan along with the other members of the Sedjro group. This loan will allow them to better meet their customers’ requests, as well as to make more profits.

loans.use: To buy peanuts and corn.

loans.name: Gbenonkpo Group

texts.fr:
GBENONKPO est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, Antoinette (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est mariée. Le couple a quatre enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Antoinette et son mari vivent ensemble avec les enfants et assurent ensemble les différentes charges des enfants. Antoinette a peu fréquenté l’école. Pour contribuer aux divers charges, 
Antoinette vend depuis dix ans, divers produits (conserves). Antoinette exerce cette activité passionnément, ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Antoinette s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et en vue d'augmenter son fonds de roulement, Antoinette sollicite un premier crédit avec les autres membres du groupe GBENONKPO. Ce crédit leur servira à mieux répondre aux demandes de leur clientèle et à se faire plus de profits.
texts.en:
Gbenonkpo is a group with three members, all of whom live in the same neighborhood. The group’s representative is called Antoinette (pictured with her hand raised in the photo), and she is married. The couple has four children, all of whom are at school and under their care.

Antoinette and her husband live together with their children, and ensure that they are provided for. Antoinette did not spend very long at school and, to contribute to paying the different household expenses, she has worked selling various products (canned goods) for the past 10 years. She is passionate about this business, and it allows her to provide for herself and her children. 

Antoinette gets her supplies in a market in Benin. In order to satisfy her customers and increase her working capital, she has requested a first loan along with the other members of the Gbenonkpo group. This loan will allow them to better meet their customers’ requests, as well as to make more profits.

loans.use: To buy various products (canned goods).

loans.name: Eusebia

texts.es:
La socia es la señora Eusebia, ahora tiene 49 años de edad, está casada y tiene 7 hijos,  vive en el distrito de Tambo Real de la provincia de Anta, la socia se dedica a la   ganadería, principalmente a la crianza de ganado vacuno, además de esto, ella también se dedica a la agricultura produciendo productos como papa, habas y maíz.
Eusebia invertirá su préstamo solicitado para comprar alimento como afrecho, forraje y chala para su ganado.
La socia está muy agradecida con KIVA por ayudarla a desarrollarse en su actividad y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas. Eusebia pertenece al banco comunal “San Bartolo de Tambo Real” distrito de Tambo Real de la provincia de Anta en Cusco – Perú.
texts.en:
This member's name is Eusebia. She is 49 years old, married and has 7 children. She lives in the district of Tambo Real in the province of Anta. She works raising livestock, mainly cattle. She also is a farmer and grows products such as potatoes, beans and corn.

Eusebia will invest the loan she has asked for in buying feed such as bran, fodder and corn husks for her cattle. She is very grateful to KIVA for helping her to develop in her activity and she is committed to making her payments. Eusebia belongs to the “San Bartolo de Tambo Real” communal bank in the district of Tambo Real of the province of Anta in Cuzco – Peru.

loans.use: to buy feed for her cattle

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fertilizer and to cover the cost of labor

loans.name: Agustino

texts.es: El señor Agustino casado con la señora Nicasia hace de 7 años, ambos con una instrucción de nivel primario, viven en una zona rural Comunidad Aguirre "2" hacia el sud del pueblo de Colomi tienen 3 hijos dependientes delos cuales estudian 2. El señor Agustino se dedica al servicio de transporte con vehículo propio afiliado en sindicato de Autotransportes Aguirre con ruta Aguirre-Cbba-Sacaba a la vez son agricultores cultivan en herencia de terreno de sus padres con rotación de cultivos papa que mayormente se dedica la esposa aparte de cuidar a sus hijos y mandar a la escuela de esta forma ellos se mantienen económicamente, como también nos dicen que  recientemente hicieron construir su casita y lo invirtieron todo el ahorro que tenían, les falto dinero para comprar insumos agrícolas (semilla de papa). Por ultimo nos cuentan ahora van a poder sembrar con más tranquilidad ya que tenían parcelas preparadas para la siembra.
texts.en: Agustino has been married to Nicasia for 7 years. Both of them have a primary school education and they live the rural area of Comunidad Aguirre "2", south of the town of Colomi. They have 3 dependent children, 2 of which are in school. Agustin works in transportation service with his own vehicle. He is affiliated with the Autotransportes Aguirre union with the Aguirre-Cbba-Sacaba route. They are also farmers who grow on land they inherited from their parents. They rotate potato crops. Mostly his wife does this, apart from caring for the children and getting them to school. In this way, they support themselves. They tell us they just built their little house and invested all of the savings that they had, so they didn't have the money to buy the agricultural materials (potato seeds). They tell us they are going to be able to plant a lot more easily because they have the land parcels ready for the planting.

loans.use: to buy agricultural products such as potato seeds.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy work tools.

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.es: El señor Eduardo de 37 años de edad casado con la señora Emiliana más de 3 años, ambos con una instrucción de nivel primario con 3 hijos dependientes, la familia vive en una comunidad lejana Corani Pampa hacia el norte de Colomi más de 19 años. Don Eduardo y su esposa se dedican a la actividad agrícola dentro del año tienen ingresos económicos de la venta de papa, locoto, cultivando en  terreno propio de 3 has Sindicato Tholar con rotación de cultivos a la vez realiza servicio de transporte de la comunidad hacia Colomi los días de feria semanal, Don Eduardo nos comenta que necesitan un crédito urgentemente para comprar abono orgánico (gallinaza) y plantines de locoto ya que no le resulto el almacigo por cuenta propia (reproducción de plantines de locoto), el ahorro que tenían gastaron en compra de semilla de papa y otros gastos familiares  como también en alquiler del tractor agrícola (para preparación de terreno arado-rotabado). Finalmente el señor Eduardo y la esposa nos dicen que en la comunidad es la época de siembra (campaña agrícola), además tenían ya preparados sus parcelas para cultivar, se sintieron muy felices, siempre así luchare para que a mi familia no les falte y que mis hijos tengan un mejor futuro.
texts.en: Eduardo is 37 years old. He has been to married to Emiliana for more than 3  years. They noth have a primary school education and 3 dependent children. The family has lived in the remote community of Corani Pampa north of Colomi for more than 19 years. Eduardo and his wife work in agriculture. During the year, they have income from selling potatoes and locoto peppers. They grow on their own land, 3 hectares, with crop rotation. Eduardo also provides transportaion service from the community to Colomi on weekly market days. He belongs to the Sindicato Tholar workers group.  Eduardo tells us that they urgently need a loan to buy fertilizer (chicken manure). The savings they had was spent on buying potato seeds and other family expenses. He also needs to rent an agricultural tractor (to prepare the land with a roto-tiller). Finally, Eduardo and his wife tell us that it is planting time in the community. They also have their land parcels ready for cultivation and they feel very happy. " I will always fight for my family so they will lack for nothing and for my children to have a better future."

loans.use: to buy potato seeds and rent a tractor to prepare his land.
